title: Protecting and Restoring NZ’s Biodiversity
text:
This HiveMind closed on 22 September 2019.

Scoop and PEP would like to thank the 96 people who submitted statements, the 536 people who took part by casting 29,802 votes and the 443 people who voted enough times to be assigned to an opinion group. Scoop will publish a detailed report on the findings in late October 2019.

Email hivemind@scoop.co.nz if you have any queries.

comments.text: We should recognise and value our indigenous ecosystems for their contribution to global biodiversity. We've lost so much already
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity consultation needs to include experts from a variety of contexts in which experience and expertise has been gained.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The roles and responsibilities of various agencies needs to be clearer so public understand who is responsible for what
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Community conservation groups be better supported through more funding, better access to information and minimising paperwork
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tourists should be charged slightly more for seeing e.g. a kiwi, than a NZ citizen, and that extra money should go towards conservation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to act now, before it's too late, and future generations miss out on our wonderful nature.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We have taken so much from this land already. It's time to give back.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We don't deserve to call ourselves Kiwis if we won't make reasonable efforts to save the Kiwi, and our other precious native species.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: New Zealanders don't see or interact enough with their native species so don't have a big enough drive to want to save them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Dogs should be kept on the leash at all times on/near wildlife hotspot beaches to prevent injuring wildlife, and this needs to be enforced.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need a plan to deal with cats in New Zealand.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Everyone can make a difference, even if it's something small like a backyard native bird feeder or a small donation to a conservation group.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More exposure to our unique endangered birdlife, like Sirocco the Kakapo, will help to raise awareness about why we need to save our species
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More and larger predator-free ecosanctuaries on the mainland are a step in the right direction.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More public knowledge about the science behind 1080 and the work DoC do is needed for conservation efforts to move forwards.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There needs to be more education about conservation and its importance in schools.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Muttonbirding should no longer be allowed. We need to move on from the past and look towards the future of all species.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The youth need to be hugely involved in this - it is their future we are deciding here, their voices deserve to be heard and acted on.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should be a scheme for the trapping or shooting of wild / feral rabbits and the sale of their meat.  Far better than poisoning...
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity needs to be defined in a way that suits Aotearoa, all of us, not a metro view, or pakeha view or rural.  We cant reverse time.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Iwi & small-scale land owners could use low productivity/erodible land for long-rotation totara and rimu plantations.= Habitat,fruit,timber.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need more trees on hillsides and coastlines to avoid erosion.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Predators could be managed by the public at lower cost to DOC with a bounty incentive, resulting in more people outdoors for a good cause
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hunters spend more time in around indigenous and non-indigenous species than many other people, their advice should be sought and valued.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our buildings should support biodiversity more e.g. more green walls and roofs, reuse of grey water, etc
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to care for the foundations of the natural world (e.g. microbes, worms, beetles) and the insects, algae, lichens and other life at the bottom of the food chain, in addition to the big animals.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Alternatives to mowed lawns need to be more acceptable. Let a bit more wilderness into gardens
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Clear and concise
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A key part of the solution is changing the way most New Zealanders think.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Most New Zealanders currently believe pest and biodiversity management are somebody elses problem.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The solutions to our biodiversity and pest control problems already exist - we just need to be willing to pay what it really costs.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Responsible hunting of introduced species should be encouraged, & the right of a  responsible hunting community to do so should be protected
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Eradicating predators would be more acheivable if less was spent on poison (1080) and public participation encouraged with a bounty system.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Game animals (deer, tahr, chamois, trout etc) must be recognised as a renewable source of conservation revenue, to be carefully managed.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Conservation minded hunters are valuable in their contribution to management of introduced species, and their efforts should encouraged more
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Introduced species game animals (deer, tahr, chamois, etc) must be managed in partnership and consultation with the hunting community.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Democracy is great for engagement but expertise is important, too.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity is too important for politicians to decide about. They need to enact what experts advise regardless of political desire.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: People need to open-minded educate themselves on 1080 - I was unsure but after extensive research I see how absolutely necessary it is
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Zoos should play a stronger role in educating us about biodiversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Science and matauranga Māori are both important, but we need more than just those two kinds of knowledge.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Voting in Hivemind is interesting and engaging, but it takes experts to figure out what really matters.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Tourism must be managed to protect biodiversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity needs to happen where people can experience it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Golf courses could be put to much better use, increasing biodiversity in towns and making it visible.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: People should mow their lawns less, and let a bit more wilderness into their gardens.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We're running out of time.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Scholars in all disciplines need to contribute to this work, not only scientists and engineers.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Urban dwellers are too far from nature to know what needs to be done. Rural voices need to be raised alongside the urban majority.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Farmers have a lot of knowledge about land, plants and animals that needs to be valued and brought into the public conversation.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More diversity in farming (e.g. farm and sell breed-specific milks) would contribute culturally to our work on nature's diversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Diversifying New Zealand's culture will improve opportunities to support the diversity of nature. E.g we will become open to broader diets.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Soil health matters, too. Let's look after the microbes, worms, beetles and things at the foundation of the natural world.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Mowed lawns are a problem. We need alternatives to be made acceptable.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: None of this is news. We've known it for decades, and everyone who's been resisting it all this time needs to get out of the way NOW.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Economics and business aren't the problems. Selfishness is.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Architects need to incorporate biodiversity provisions into building design.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Royal Society needs to exercise a primary authority here, not the government. The government are not experts.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to care for insects, algae, lichens and other life at the bottom of the food chain, in addition to the big animals.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Roadsides and berms need to be treated and valued as biodiverse wildlife space.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Land development must nourish the groundwater as a foundation for soil health, not drain it all to the sea.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Urban waterways need to be made into nature corridors and nature-compatible recreation spaces, not buried in pipes.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Cat owners should keep their cats indoors, or at least stop them from roaming free without supervision.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Home gardeners have a role to play through the plants and gardening methods that they choose.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Urban landscaping, such as city council plantings, need to prioritise biodiversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Town planning needs to prioritise biodiversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: This isn't a Māori-and-Pākehā issue. It's an issue for all New Zealanders needing the diverse understanding that all cultures bring.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity and environmental stewardships are fundamental obligations of landowners.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We are part of nature, not separate from it. Nature has no right separate from us, but when it falls, we fall too.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Make space for the young. The old who got us into this mess are not only stubborn, but essentially stupid.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Domestic cats need to be recognised as a serious but manageable threat to biodiversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to work on the biodiversity of the sea, as well as of the land.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I no longer accept that it is economy versus ecology. A healthy biodiverse environment is essential for farming sustainability.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Native forest soil and ground plants must be protected from browsing mammals to maintain healthy forests, water quality and reduce erosion.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Although consultation with stakeholders is a good idea, the democratic process as it stands is too clunky to achieve conservation success
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Participants deserve to be shown the voting on all the statements submitted.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ's economic interests need to be put aside for the moment, without our environment we have nothing.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: My generation has been growing watching things get worse and worse, but we are powerless to stop it, as we essentially have no voice.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The future of Aotearoa's natural environment, ecosystems, biodiversity seems hopeless. It's too little, too late.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need radical change to address the problems we've created. But our current systems may not allow for this to happen.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The way we currently produce animals for food is damaging our ecosystems
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If people continue to see nature as a resource to be exploited, we will never make real change. We need to value it for it's own sake.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The processes of westernization, colonization, and capitalism underlie the erosion of our ecosystems.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to stop valuing economic systems over the natural ones they disrupt.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our current farming practices are not sustainable
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to assess the impact of all introduced species to our ecosystems, including those we economically benefit from
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Animal agriculture has an undeniable negative impact on our environment, and serious measures  need to be taken to address this
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Grazing should cease causing harm to our living freshwater ecosystems
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Conservation jobs should attract higher pay rates to attract and keep talented, knowledgeable and committed people
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: When profit is made from degrading our forest, oceans, waterways, land and air it should be taxed to fund restoration and repair
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The natural state of man is the  expression of such gratitude, appreciation and compassion that ALL animals love to be in his/her presence.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Us humans have destroyed this stunning country and planet - it’s is time to give back what we have stolen — many hands make light work 🙏
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Stop using indiscriminate poisons. Stop lying to the public about the safety of poisons. Stop teaching kids you should kill harmless joeys .
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Save our speecies , BAN1080
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ban 1080 easy let nature fix what you broke
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Please stop using poisons in New Zealand.They are no tool they are killers of all species.There are better ways.Love Nature stop killing her
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Whether they live in a city or in a rural area, every New Zealanders opinion matters.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: DOC has very little support from the general public due to their obsession on poisoning our environment and food chain with 1080.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Sanctuaries, private, Maori & public
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I no longer accept that it is economy or ecology.  Rather that a healthy biodiverse environment is essential for farming sustainability.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Be more careful about where poison is dropped. Read again the 1080 SDS.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Stick to trapping rather than poison in areas people can reach by foot/quad. Reduce non-target deaths by contamination of their food chain.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ban aerial 1080 get more people involved lots of traps and proactive non toxic solutions its all there we just need to get off the poison
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: BAN TEN80
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Give nature legal personhood similar to the Whanganui River. Nature should represented by trustees appointed by iwi and the govt, and have standing in planning law and the courts.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Current commercial monoculture forestry is damaging our environment. Mixed forestry with higher value species should be promoted
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In the face of a changing climate, reslient practices and species will become increasingly important
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The sale and use of pesticides and herbicides should be restricted with the aim of creating a totally organic environment
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Community environmental effort will be constantly undermined by economy-based decision making unless there are major system changes
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Human beings need to manage and maintain ecosystems and biodiversity in perpetuity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Man was created with domain over nature - we should use it. If it dies, it will be replaced - that's the nature of living things on earth
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Establish a partnership between the agriculture industry and government to develop and promote farming practices that protect and restore our biodiversity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Threatened indigenous plants should be protected by stronger legal mechanisms
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity habitat and climate change response should go hand in hand
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: This consultation can be skewed by bloc-voting from anti-1080 partisans.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hunting of wild pigeons/kereru should never be legal again, for any race.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Control of most introduced bird species is inadequate.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: 1080 is a cruel and indiscriminate poison with no antidote. Most people are against aerial 1080.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Man was created with domain over nature - we should use it, and it it dies it will be replaced - that's the nature of living things on earth
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Give nature a legal persona and let it have standing in planning law and the courts, represented by trustees appointed by iwi and the govt
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: In rural NZ, private property does not give the right to destroy specie's habitat and homes, just because you "own" the land
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need more protection corridors that run from the sea to the mountains, managed to allow native species to thrive
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: as sea level rises, we should retreat and allow native plants and animals to migrate into the space we vacate - plants and birds need it
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Why not put the Maui dolphins in the Napier aquarium to breed and raise money to help save them
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: New Zealanders care about nature and our native species
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The resource management act review must address cumulative adverse effects - many minor losses add up to significant losses otherwise
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Many private land owners will protect native biodiversity on their land if they know how to, and are assisted/encouraged
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ is a unique world treasure  we need to assure it has a future
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: For all predators to be killed off new laws will be needed to enforce this plan across all lands.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Maori are being included in this plan because there's 1 million hectares of Maori land that needs to be poisoned.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There are many exciting new ways to properly engage with nature this plan isn't one of them.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Killing for conservation is an example of human logic being applied to natural systems, that operate outside of our proper understanding.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Rather than gaining a balanced view this survey is designed to channel people's thinking in a certain way. =Zero proper discussion.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: NZ is being asked to allow a bureaucracy to impose a view of nature on natural systems we have little understanding of.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The world is in a continual state of change and evolution. As one plant or animal disappears another takes its place.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: As no ecosystem is ever browser  or predator free trying to eliminate them completely is both undesirable and impossible.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Prohibiting dogs from entering forests with kiwis and beaches with nesting dotterels needs to be taken more seriously.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There aren't enough endemic bird species being bred in captivity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Preventing the illegal ownership of possums and ferrets as pets needs to be enforced more seriously.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: DOC have been starved of finance for many years and while that has been redressed slightly more backing is needed for biodiversity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity habitat and climate change response should go hand in hand - plant specification, farming practice can contribute to both.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: When NZ species are clearly doomed due to climate crisis, we must stop pest control - this will be pointless, so inhumane.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Returning forests to an unbrowsed state is nonsense. Moa browsed extensively from lowlands to alpine areas. Browsers are part of our nature!
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Our livelihoods must be connected to restoring nature to shift from our degenerative economy and stop the global ecological collapse
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The government must commit $$ to an implementation plan for the Strategy
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Farmers need to be encouraged to move away from dairy and beef farming to arable farming.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: A stand-alone non-binding strategy will not be sufficient to ensure biodiversity protection
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Threatened Plants need legal protection
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to find alternatives to using 1080 poison for pest control
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should be a working partnership between the agriculture industry & the government working towards biodiversity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The government should direct the agriculture industry to both improve biodiversity and to develop sustainably
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Get locals to help identify and set up as many 'mainland sanctuaries' as possible.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Trapping for rats, etc should be fully subsidised on private property close to national and regional parks, and island sanctuaries so that native populations can expand beyond the protected areas
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need more advertising campaigns about NZ's unique flora and fauna so we feel the need to protect our species and so that we know what to do
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Pest plants are a significant threat to indigenous biodiversity.  More resources and focus is needed to address this issue.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More great advertising like this video with a call to specific action - tell Kiwis what we need to do to help protect our vulnerable species
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Love your video on NZ's unique flora and fauna. We need more advertising campaigns like this so we feel the need to protect our species.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Private property close to national or regional parks should be fully subsidised for trapping rodents.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Time to bring back gorse inspections for land. The law used to be that gorse must be removed. What happened to that?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Time to subsidise backyard trapping in Auckland close to island sanctuaries before the birds start flying over and get eaten by our rats.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Kakapo need a warmer place to live than the deep South. Time to bring more up North where they once lived in abundance. So sad so many died.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need to identify as many possible 'mainland sanctuaries' as possible. Get locals to identify potential habitats and get started.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The government needs to provide direction to the agriculture industry to both improve biodiversity and ensure sustainable development.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The strategy should include measures for improved connection and wellbeing of people.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need a way to ensure enduring financial commitment of central and local government to action for the whole duration of the strategy.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Any biodiversity strategy governance should include young people to speak for the future generations
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There needs to be continual shift towards the mindset that outdoor cats have a significant negative impact on native biodiversity
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Eliminate populations of non-native species that are valued for recreational or economic reasons but that negatively impact native species e.g. tahr, trout
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Allow seaweed aquaculture, which will improve biodiversity, sequester more carbon than trees and reduce ocean acidification
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: End aerial 180 drops
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The biggest threat to biodiversity in our oceans and beaches is plastic pollution. We need to stop importing it, making it and buying it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Clean up the Waikato river
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Seaweed aquaculture will improve biodiversity,sequester more carbon than trees+reduce ocean acidification.Legislation currently prohibits it
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Education standards should require educational field trips to natural spaces for all school children.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More no-take marine reserves should be created, especially in the habitat of endangered animals, like Maui dolphins and endangered seabirds
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We could switch NZ's main meat source to wild deer/pig/trout/goat, hunting levels down so they are less impactful on natives
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If we keep pigs/deer/trout, they should be made a mainstream food source (instead of farming) and try to control levels to feed people
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: For hunting/fishing, restricted areas could be made and require bookings to reduce number of hunters in bush at the same time.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Hapu should be involved BUT some may use that as an excuse to keep/exploit land which could be used for conservation. Word laws carefully
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Distributed decisions re:land use must account/forecast impact across human, social, natural, production, intellectual & financial metrics
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Open-data commons, curating/visualising enviro, social & financial data frm ALL users of whenua will help us make decisions democratically
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Populations of non-native species that have a recreational or economic benefit (eg tahr hunting, trout fishing) should not be maintained.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Instead of focusing on protecting flagship species, we should focus on protecting entire ecosystems, which may include those species.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I find this kind of participation frustrating because it does not, probably cannot, include deliberation with one's fellow citizens.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Instead of saving 'species' save environments where multiple species coexist ie areas where kiwi can thrive as well as other species
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The clean water issue having farmers both hill country & flat land under the one umbrella is unfair as the situation is entirely different.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There needs to be a stronger emphasis on retaining our endemic invertebrate diversity. Without them our fragile ecosystem wouldn't exist.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Nature can manage itself. Humans are the cause of all perceived problems. Management is unnecessary. Leave wild places wild.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Allowing government/politicians to manage nature is the main problem. Stop poisoning our wild food.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity means encouraging all forms of life to prosper. The current economic scarcity based system is unable to coexist with this idea.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Everything works for everything; we need to have sustainable systems, not endless consumption and growth.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Water management to prevent degradation is key to success in land and biodiversity management
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ownership of water rights should not allow degradation of the resource. Stronger management, quality and quantity standards are needed.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Protection and enhancement will mean different things, they need to be clear so everyone knows they are talking about the same things
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: genetic manipulation is best left to the experts, viruses.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The only way of rectifying the environmental issues is less humans. Either we control our numbers or nature will, unlikely to be "humane"
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The "economy" is a subset of the environment, economics would have us believe it is separate as only money matters
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It is neo-liberal economics, at its core it is a religion with a very savage hook, interest (usury it was called) which necessitates growth
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: nature has the right exist, what ignorant hubris, how disconnected is that statement from the world we live in?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Deer/pig/trout are excellent food source, we can never get rid of them so control and use as such
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Forget the crown, NZ is for NZers. That is all we need to understand. Unfortunately most of our ruling class consider others before NZers...
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Stewardship is not a race based decision, we are all homo sap spp, the sooner we all realise there is nowhere to run the better
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We already know what the problem is, no amount of science or tech is going to change it. Overshoot it is called, all else is symptom.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Unfortunately the private landowner may do things to his/her land that are damaging for the country, we are all temporary utilisers of NZ
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: DOC cost per dead possum is about $25, so a $10 bounty gets lots of youngsters into the bush (connections all round) solves several issues.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Funding be given to gene research on changes in species that allow them to breed past sustainable levels and ways to return this to normal
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Farming monocultures are harmful, funding should be given to research and promote diverse  systems of farming.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Water management to prevent degradation is key to success in land and bio management  while their management benefits water, they rely on it
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ownership of water rights should not allow degradation of the resource.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Ownership of land rights grant you the temporary use of it, the land continues in the community after you, it is not the right to degrade it
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: If climate change proceeds, there will come a point where we have to give up on protecting NZ biodiversity.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Gathering meat though hunting game species should  be considered as a valuable resource
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Particularly in urban areas, we need to give greater weight to definite benefits for all from trees, less to tiny risk of injury to 1.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The cost of monitoring the state and change of biodiversity values may exceed the cost of management
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The best strategy is to give land back to Nature and allow natural processes to create new ecosystems.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The existing combination of introduced and native plants and animals are the ecosystems of the future.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The Maori perspective should not be bought, bent and manipulated in order to incorporate it into what is essentially a pakeha view.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: All life is precious and interconnected. This should be the basis for any plan.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The wisdom of nature is greater than our own. We have little understanding of what we are doing.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity includes all life forms. In nature there are no such things as Pests. There is no such thing as being cruel to be kind.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: More focus needs to be shifted from charismatic fauna to lesser known, threatened species.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There should be more onus on peer reviewed science in decision making that affects biodiversity, such as cat control.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: the strategy needs to include most species. not just indigeous
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I don't like using poisons  for pest control but necessary evil until something better is developed.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Decisions on funding for pest control are made by the same people and successful innovations developed by outsiders are dismissed
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Barren farmed landscapes have become a mental health issue. They must have recognisable native vegetation within it.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Roadsides and other public land are currently pest plant corridors. Where possible this aspect must be eliminated.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: The impacts of deer, pigs and trout need to be clearly stated and their cultural links dealt with.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Biodiversity values on private land can be a liability from a development perspective
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Remove limitations placed on public engagement such as legislative barriers and eurocentric concepts of natural heritage to reduce harm.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: We need governance that has the mandate to represent community groups & doesn't take western approaches to influence decision making spaces

comments.text: We need to remove systemic and structural forces that impose harm to preserving our natural and cultural heritage.

comments.text: We need to recognise the concept of cultural landscapes and the layers of meaning and connections within a landscape. Reverse western values

comments.text: Herbicides and Pesticide use must be limited. Land clearing or change of land use that disrupts terrestrial ecosystems must stop.

comments.text: We should innovate to become more inclusive of nature and biodiversity in our city/town designs.

comments.text: the biodiversity strategy must be measureable

comments.text: Please stop poisoning our lovely forests from the sky with deadly poison. Mammals and rural hunters are part of our diversity.

comments.text: Protecting and enhancing our environment is good for our economy and our society.
